lead_paragraph: The driver of a high-speed passenger train involved in one of Europe’s worst rail accidents in recent years had openly relished the idea of racing past the authorities.

byline.contributor: Silvia Taulés reported from Santiago de Compostela, and Doreen Carvajal from Paris. Stephen Castle contributed reporting from London, and Caroline Brothers from Paris.
byline.original: By SILVIA TAULÉS and DOREEN CARVAJAL

snippet: The driver of a high-speed passenger train involved in one of Europe’s worst rail accidents in recent years had openly relished the idea of racing past the authorities....
abstract: Francisco Jose Garzon Amo, driver of train that was said to be traveling about 120 miles per hour when it crashed near Santiago de Compostela, Spain, has openly posted on Facebook his desire to exceed the speed limit; 80 people were killed in the crash, making it Spain's worst rail accident since 1972, when 86 people were killed in the southwest of the country.

headline.main: Spanish Train Inquiry Focuses on Driver With a Taste for Speed
headline.print_headline: Spanish Train Inquiry Focuses on Driver With a Taste for Speed
